intro: Lupinus noldekae, commonly known as the Noldeka lupine, is a flowering plant species native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, erect growth habit and clusters of pea-like flowers that range in color from purple to pink. The plant belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and possesses typical features of the genus Lupinus, including compound leaves and pods. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Lupinus noldekae plays a role in nitrogen fixation, contributing to soil fertility in its native environment.
